Posts.Content: skigrl wrote: 3 weeks after my mastectomy i developed severe nerve pain. It consumed my waking hours. My oncologist prescribed Lyrica. It took about 3 weeks for it to kick in fully, but i have to say i am pain free. I may try to wean off it a little bit to see how it works. I take 100mg at bedtime, because it makes me to loopy during the day, and i am loopy enough already to have extra help in that department. So for any of you out there with nerve pain give Lyrica a try. Dx 10/2/2008, IDC, 5cm, Stage IIIA, Grade 3, 1/3 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Lyrica stopped my nerve pain skigrl skigrl

If it was an enchodronam they said it shouldnt hurt....well guess what mine hurts!!!! So maybe i will have answers next week. Thanks for everyones reply.

Posts.Title: where are your bone mets located?? skigrl lady4law

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2010 01:12PM skigrl wrote: Hi 3Katz, Yes i have had a pet scan last may, that is when they found what they are thinking is the enchondronam. My onc. sent me to see a orthepedic onc. because the radiologist at the hospital i go to couldnt be 100% sure what it was that showed up on my scan. So i went last may to see the ortho onc. he pretty much thoughtit was the enchondronam but also wasnt 100%....he said come back in 9 months to see if it has changed at all. He said it shouldnt be painful, but it is and has been getting worse. My leg is about an inch  more swollen the the other leg also. I am hoping it is just the benign condition. I was thinking of asking if i could take zometa just as a precaution. Do you take that? I am sorry you have so many lesions, crap i am sorry you got cancer!!!! my life has changed SO much in SO many ways since diagnosis. Some say cancer makes you appreciate what you have more, bullsh*t..i WAS appreciative before cancer and i WAS living my life to the fullest before this monster took my full life away.... i am NOT enjoying life as much as i did before cancer that is for sure. Maybe one day that will change.

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2010 03:25PM skigrl wrote: Hi 3katz, I had to reschedule my appt. because of a snowstorm we are getting. I am in the mountains of Maine and are expected to get one to two feet!!!WOOHOO!!! It is now scheduled for March 17th. I figured i waited for 9 months , what is one more month. To respond to your previous post, I did not have an MRI , i had an x- ray of my leg and it showed something in my fibula. (i think i said tibia before). Like you 3katz, i too am still living my life to the fullest, i have 2 young kids 7 & 9 and we do LOTS with them. I hike, bike ,ski swim, run,kayak, travel........as much as i can, however it is not like it used to be, age and chemo have slooowwed me down some. But i still do it,in fact i am planning a winter camping trip soon. There are some days when i get down about having had to endure this disease, especially when i look at my body and see how it has changed. I HATE IT! BUT i am alive, and plan on being here for my kids. I cant imagine them not having me be in their lives. During my darkest time, during chemo when i felt like i was not going to make it through treatment #4, i thought that i would take my kids with me because i couldnt leave them behind. Glad those days are gone. PHEW! Thanks for checking in, i will let you know what happens with the appt.

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2012 05:24PM skigrl wrote: My neuropathy started two months after my last chemo of ACT. I tried Lyrica , but hated how I felt on it, even when taking it at bedtime, I also gained about 15 pounds which I am still trying to loose. So I went off the Lyrica. The neuropathy got so bad when I laid down at night that I was hardly sleeping and trying to function during the day with minimal sleep. Having a job and two young kids, I was a zombie . At my wits end I went to the local clinic and talked with the on call doc and told him my problem no sleep, blah blah. I wanted a sleeping pill, I was desperate, he said no sleeping pill. Instead he gave me a script for Amytriptyline. It is a anti depressant but also turned out to help people with neuropathy, thank god I took it, about two weeks into it I am sleeping through the night, don't feel the pain in my feet nearly as much as when I took Lyrica . I wake up refreshed. And also in a good mood because it is an anti depressant. I take 20 mg a night before bed and good night Irene! I plan to be on this med for a loooong time. Maybe your mom can talk to the doc about Amitriptyline.
Posts.Title: Neuropathy mkkjd60 skigrl

Posts.Content: Dec 5, 2010 05:16PM skigrl wrote: You are amazingly strong. It must be like a weight off your shoulders to say "Hey, calm down take it one day at a time" You really never know how your path is going to go from one day to the next, so might as well try and stay calm. If you dont mind my asking, how does your Dr. know the lump is mets? Did you point the lump out to him or did he just start rubbing your head? Does it hurt? I have several lumps pop up on my head that i have not noticed before, i  have an appt. in Feb , maybe i should mention them. I really need to try and stay in the calm frame of mind also. Whenever i start feeling anxious i will remember what you are doing.
Posts.Title: Strangely Calm FightnF8 justjudie

Posts.Content: Sep 23, 2013 04:43AM skigrl wrote: I am located in the western mountains of Maine, the colors are starting to turn for us right now, we are no where near peak yet. I just returned from a 2 day camping trip with my daughter middle school to Acadia National Park. It is absolutely beautiful! There are trolley tours right located on West St. In the town of Bar Harbor, it will take you up Caddilac Mountain(first place to see the sunrise in the USA) and around the historic parts of the town .if you go don't miss "diver Ed" he and his wife operate a boat that holds about 70 people they take itinto the harbor and will dive with a camera and microphone and talk about the sea life he is encountering , you can view it all on his giant flat screen, then he will bring it all up to the boat for hands on for all on the boat and he is hilarious But the beauty of Acadia is breathtaking. I cannot believe my husband and I have traveled all over the world and havent explored this gem literally in our back yard. We plan on going soon and bringing or renting bikes to take on the carriage Roads. The foliage should be turning nicely around the time of you trip.
Posts.Title: Dream Vacation to New England in the Fall TonyaB susan_02143

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2008 05:28AM skigrl wrote: Hi NikiC, I also have the horrible pain, i had a mastectomy on nov 6th. My pain developed 2-3 weeks after surgery. My oncologist asked me to describe it....i said the worst sunburn you could ever get followed by someone rubbing the highest grit sandpaper on your skin...and NOT stopping!!!!! He prescribed Lyrica for me, it has not worked for me yet, also makes me feel loopy, my plastic surgeon gave me a script of lidocaine patches to put directly on the skin....it numbs it a little, enough to let me do some light activities. It seems to be the only thing on my mind...people talk to me but i rarely hear what they say because i only think of the pain constantly nagging at me. Mine pain became so bad last night that i ended up drinking several glasses of wine and taking a pain pill to deal with it and let me sleep, i am afraid this will become a nightly way to deal with this horrble pain, just so i can get some rest. It's not enough that you have a cancer diagnosis, cutting a breast off, having to go through treatments, and now horrible pain, what else can come this way, anything good? Sorry to rant but the pain seems to make me a different person, i really dont care about other things right now except trying to get comfortable. Maybe i will write to santa and ask him for some relief. ;>) skigrl
